These two words have similar meanings and usage:



å…¶æ¬¡ (qÃ­cÃ¬)

This word means "next" or "secondly." It's used to introduce the next point or step in a sequence or list.



æ¥ç€ (jiÄ“zhe)

This word also means "next" or "then." It's used to indicate the continuation or succession of actions or events.

Both words can be used to transition to the next point or step in a sequence, but å…¶æ¬¡ (qÃ­cÃ¬) is more commonly used in formal or structured contexts, such as presentations or written documents, while æ¥ç€ (jiÄ“zhe) is more commonly used in everyday speech or informal writing.

column5:
å´ (quÃ¨)

This word is used to indicate a contrast or contradiction between two clauses or sentences. It can be translated as "but," "yet," "however," or "nevertheless," and is used to express unexpected or contradictory information.



å¯æ˜¯ (kÄ›shÃ¬), ä»ç„¶ (rÃ©nglÃ¬), è€Œ (Ã©r), å€’ (dÃ o), ç„¶è€Œ (rÃ¡n'Ã©r), ä¸è¿‡ (bÃ¹guÃ²)

These are synonyms for expressing contrast, contradiction, or concession, but each has its own specific usage. å¯æ˜¯ (kÄ›shÃ¬) is used to convey a contrast or contradiction, similar to "but" or "however." ä»ç„¶ (rÃ©nglÃ¬) means "still" or "yet," and is used to indicate that a situation or condition persists. è€Œ (Ã©r) is used to connect two clauses or ideas, similar to "and" or "while." å€’ (dÃ o) is used to express a contrast or unexpected outcome. ç„¶è€Œ (rÃ¡n'Ã©r) is also used to indicate a contrast or contradiction, similar to "however" or "nevertheless." ä¸è¿‡ (bÃ¹guÃ²) is used to introduce a contrasting or concessive idea.

While å´ (quÃ¨) can be used to indicate a contrast within the same sentence, å¯æ˜¯ (kÄ›shÃ¬), ä»ç„¶ (rÃ©nglÃ¬), è€Œ (Ã©r), å€’ (dÃ o), ç„¶è€Œ (rÃ¡n'Ã©r), and ä¸è¿‡ (bÃ¹guÃ²) have their own specific nuances and usage. Additionally, ç„¶è€Œ (rÃ¡n'Ã©r) is more formal and literary compared to å´ (quÃ¨).

column3: (particle equivalent to å•Š after a vowel, expressing surprise or doubt)
